commit_message:
Add support to update keystone for bifrost

Adds the playbook steps required to add ironic
to the keystone catalog, create a service account,
create roles, and ultimately create a baremetal tenant
with a user and baremetal_admin rights.

Change-Id: I1a2e7229b24ebfe12b5b80f1a937baba2835ab1b

Please set one to "false". when: > noauth_mode | bool == true and enable_keystone is defined and enable_keystone | bool == true - name: "Populate keystone for Bifrost" include: keystone_setup.yml when: enable_keystone is defined and enable_keystone | bool == true

commit_message:
Added prerequisites and configure IaC extension

Added the following sub-sections to the "Modify your
environment using Git repository section":

- Prerequisites
- Configure the Fuel IaC extension

Change-Id: I437800bc86885ddbe294b12bfd30040e189711be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/19/404919/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Configure the Fuel IaC extenstion ================================= To be able to deploy changes from a Git repository, you need to clone the Fuel Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) extension and configure it on the Fuel Master node. **To configure the IaC extension:** #. Install ``git`` and ``python-pip``: :: yum install git python-pip #. Clone the IaC Fuel extension repository: :: git clone https://github.com/openstack/fuel-nailgun-extension-iac #. Change the current directory to ``fuel-nailgun-extension-iac``. :: cd fuel-nailgun-extension-iac #. Install the required packages: :: pip install -r requirements.txt #. Install the ``setup.py`` package: :: python setup.py install #. Synchronize the Nailgun database: :: nailgun_syncdb #. Restart the Nailgun service: :: systemctl restart nailgun.service #. Verify the extension is installed correctly by viewing the list of installed extensions: :: fuel2 extension list **Example of system response:** :: +-------------------+---------+-------------------+---------------------+ | name | version | description | provides | +-------------------+---------+-------------------+---------------------+ | fuel_external_git | 1.0.0 | Nailgun extension | [] | | | | which uses git | | | | | repo for config | | | | | files. | | +-------------------+---------+-------------------+---------------------+ #. Enable the extension for the required environment: :: fuel2 env extension enable <env_id> -E fuel_external_git

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-01 22:44:16.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/common_functions.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/3bd847ccd63d209c13091dd4f5d8f3de3102aadf', 'message': "Run log collection in parallel

since most OVB nodes are going to be on separate compute nodes we

commit_message:
Run log collection in parallel

Log collection takes a little while on each overcloud node, and
since most OVB nodes are going to be on separate compute nodes we
should be able to run those commands in parallel without any major
drawbacks (the one exception would be extract_logs which is run on
the undercloud, but that seems to be a very small part of the log
collection runtime).

This is done by starting the group of log collection commands in the
background and then using the 'wait' command to pause until they are
all finished.

Change-Id: If65e0e460467185a5695cf214272ef35e41c3f03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/70/405670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Log collection takes a while. Let's start these in the background # so they can run in parallel, then we'll wait for them to complete # after they're all running. ( $TARCMD $HOME/*.log > $WORKSPACE/logs/undercloud.tar.xz extract_logs undercloud ) & ( scp $SSH_OPTIONS $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-ci/scripts/get_host_info.sh heat-admin@${SANITIZED_ADDRESS}:/tmp timeout -s 15 -k 600 300 ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP sudo /tmp/get_host_info.sh ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP $JLOGCMD ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP $TARCMD > $WORKSPACE/logs/${NAME}.tar.xz extract_logs $NAME ) & # Wait for the commands we started in the background to complete wait
deleted_lines: $TARCMD $HOME/*.log > $WORKSPACE/logs/undercloud.tar.xz extract_logs undercloud scp $SSH_OPTIONS $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-ci/scripts/get_host_info.sh heat-admin@${SANITIZED_ADDRESS}:/tmp timeout -s 15 -k 600 300 ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP sudo /tmp/get_host_info.sh ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP $JLOGCMD ssh $SSH_OPTIONS heat-admin@$IP $TARCMD > $WORKSPACE/logs/${NAME}.tar.xz extract_logs $NAME

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-30 21:16:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/1066af9a3caffb328df7dba2ca9b10d5ba9ae737', 'message': 'Use original package name when updating requirements

For i.e. "posix_ipc", the update-requirements command created an
update to use "posix-ipc" instead of "posix_ipc".

See for example:
        http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.concurrency/\
        commit/?id=45ff5571380ea4fbd1cab6dca76bd05ebe59b317

For pypi this works but it's more difficult to translate this name into
something useful for system packages.
It's also confusing that the global-requirements.txt has different
requirements than then projects because of the renaming.

commit_message:
Use original package name when updating requirements

For i.e. "posix_ipc", the update-requirements command created an
update to use "posix-ipc" instead of "posix_ipc".

See for example:
        http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.concurrency/\
        commit/?id=45ff5571380ea4fbd1cab6dca76bd05ebe59b317

For pypi this works but it's more difficult to translate this name into
something useful for system packages.
It's also confusing that the global-requirements.txt has different
requirements than then projects because of the renaming.
So use the pypi name for requirements.

Change-Id: I4126c382bc4d148c5ee97f1bb5bd7375341d903a

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

We should avoid using six.iteritems/keys achieve iterators. We can use
dict.items/keys instead, as it will return iterators in PY3 as well.
And dict.items/keys will more readable.

In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3 and
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I6353f0a1b423c6dbd0c71343f7919fd0de440e34

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-02 02:22:46.000000000', 'files': ['ceph/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charms.ceph/commit/c04b57a79f7e2e297aca14cd44d8ead5b4dc0eeb', 'message': "Correct reraising of exception

"}]
commit_message:
Correct reraising of exception

When an exception was caught and rethrown, it should
call 'raise' without any arguments because it shows
the place where an exception occured initially instead
of place where the exception re-raised

Change-Id: I8742aeeecb64bbd0ab5e89b1cc3d057cea5edf35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charms.ceph refs/changes/36/405736/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e: raise e

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-01 22:06:25.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b05e996ae55233235fa6feb73ddfb9f3c86958d2', 'message': "Always use python2.7 for docs target

The docs testenv doesn't work with python 3.x on our codebase.
If someone is on a platform that defaults to python => python3,
building docs will fail for them.

Closes-Bug: #1646629

Change-Id: I56f3933e89e6fe9e181517325e2d7af5110c5656
"}]
commit_message:
Always use python2.7 for docs target

The docs testenv doesn't work with python 3.x on our codebase.
If someone is on a platform that defaults to python => python3,
building docs will fail for them.

Closes-Bug: #1646629

Change-Id: I56f3933e89e6fe9e181517325e2d7af5110c5656
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/405665/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-31 16:50:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7f0ff54adf50a8d64dbc25094f4aef68c0ef4111', 'message': "placement: implement destroy() resource class

Adds ResourceClass.destroy() method to delete a custom resource class.
Deletions of standard resource classes or resource classes that are
referenced in an inventory record are forbidden.

Note to reviewers: there is a change to the resource class cache code
included here that may seem to be unrelated to the content of this
patch. The patch removes the context manager call in the
_refresh_from_db() method:

 with ctx.session.connection() as conn:

and doesn't use the context manager, instead leaving the connection
open. This is necessary to prevent errors about using a closed
connection that surfaced when writing a functional test case that tested
that deleting a custom resource class when inventory is associated with
that custom resource class.

Change-Id: I7809fa8941338b3bcef4872c13a791992e221851

commit_message:
placement: adds ResourceClass.destroy()

Adds ResourceClass.destroy() method to delete a custom resource class.
Deletions of standard resource classes or resource classes that are
referenced in an inventory record are forbidden.

Change-Id: I7809fa8941338b3bcef4872c13a791992e221851
blueprint: custom-resource-classes
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/18/391918/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_destroy_fail_no_id(self): rc = objects.ResourceClass( self.context, name='CUSTOM_IRON_NFV', ) self.assertRaises(exception.ObjectActionError, rc.destroy) def test_destroy_fail_standard(self): rc = objects.ResourceClass.get_by_name( self.context, 'VCPU', ) self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceClassCannotDeleteStandard, rc.destroy) def test_destroy(self): rc = objects.ResourceClass( self.context, name='CUSTOM_IRON_NFV', ) rc.create() rc_list = objects.ResourceClassList.get_all(self.context) rc_ids = (r.id for r in rc_list) self.assertIn(rc.id, rc_ids) rc.destroy() rc_list = objects.ResourceClassList.get_all(self.context) rc_ids = (r.id for r in rc_list) self.assertNotIn(rc.id, rc_ids) def test_destroy_fail_with_inventory(self): """Test that we raise an exception when attempting to delete a resource class that is referenced in an inventory record. """ rc = objects.ResourceClass( self.context, name='CUSTOM_IRON_NFV', ) rc.create() rp = objects.ResourceProvider( self.context, name='my rp', uuid=uuidsentinel.rp, ) rp.create() inv = objects.Inventory( resource_provider=rp, resource_class='CUSTOM_IRON_NFV', total=1, ) inv.obj_set_defaults() inv_list = objects.InventoryList(objects=[inv]) rp.set_inventory(inv_list) self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceClassInUse, rc.destroy) rp.set_inventory(objects.InventoryList(objects=[])) rc.destroy() rc_list = objects.ResourceClassList.get_all(self.context) rc_ids = (r.id for r in rc_list) self.assertNotIn(rc.id, rc_ids)

commit_message:
Move dsvm full-ssh to xenial

The periodic dsvm full-ssh job already runs on xenial, but the
check/gate ones are on trusty still. Those jobs run personality
tests, for which libguestfs >1.26 is required, which is only
available from xenial on; so moving the check/gate jobs to xenial.

Change-Id: I9fa90b534e152f0f80e64678c2d06ba18b1c2b91
Partial-bug: #1646002

commit_message:
Temporarily disable ceph in the updates job

It looks like updates are currently breaking on a Ceph-related issue,
and since the multinode updates job doesn't use ceph and is passing
this should get the job working again.  Once it's back voting we
can figure out how to fix Ceph.

Change-Id: I08924b0be702530afcd4cb3b25083a15213b0077
Related-Bug: 1641653

commit_message:
OVO: add SubnetServiceType object and code integration.

Adding SubnetServiceType to Subnet OVO as synthetic field.
It is not required to change the Subnet version, since it is not used.

Change-Id: I0ccff39dcb5e41351b0a4aeba7c98cfba24a1689
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
Update keystoneclient minimum dependency to 3.8

The 3.8 release of keystoneclient brings support for ?allow_expired
handling on auth validation. This support is required in
keystonemiddleware for extended token validation support.

Change-Id: I8a85fe46cbb28a7caeb89c54f073d2ebac3a4d2d

commit_message:
Remove marker and loop from "image list" command

Since --page-size has never worked, there is no paginate logic needs
to be implemented in "image list" command. So remove the unnecessary
loop.

And also, the marker is not necessary because --marker option has not
been implemented. Will add it back when implementing --marker option.

Change-Id: I71fea1502f92f447a49697edb52e8e82f336772f
Partial-Bug: #1540988

commit_message:
Functional test for asg max_size and min_size

It is vital to have functional test for max_size and min_size so that
we dont exceed quota and stay within capacity limits.

Change-Id: Ib9d8c11bcb08b591bd4c5c211218c342eef52b54
Partial-Bug: #1577090
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/31/310731/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat_integrationtests.common import test cooldown: 0 desired_capacity: 3 max_size: 5 min_size: 2 scale_up_policy: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: { get_resource: random_group } scaling_adjustment: 1 scale_down_policy: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: { get_resource: random_group } scaling_adjustment: -1 value_1: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.1.value]} value_2: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.2.value]} asg_size: value: {get_attr: [random_group, current_size]} desired_capacity: 3 max_size: 5 min_size: 2 value_1: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.1.random_str]} value_2: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.2.random_str]} self.assertEqual(3, len(all_values)) self.assertEqual(all_values[1], self._stack_output(stack, 'value_1')) self.assertEqual(all_values[2], self._stack_output(stack, 'value_2')) def test_asg_scale_up_max_size(self): stack_id = self.stack_create(template=self.template, expected_status='CREATE_COMPLETE') stack = self.client.stacks.get(stack_id) asg_size = self._stack_output(stack, 'asg_size') # Ensure that initial desired capacity is met self.assertEqual(3, asg_size) # send scale up signals and ensure that asg honors max_size asg = self.client.resources.get(stack_id, 'random_group') max_size = 5 for num in range(asg_size+1, max_size+2): expected_resources = num if num <= max_size else max_size self.client.resources.signal(stack_id, 'scale_up_policy') test.call_until_true(self.conf.build_timeout, self.conf.build_interval, self.check_autoscale_complete, asg.physical_resource_id, expected_resources) def test_asg_scale_down_min_size(self): stack_id = self.stack_create(template=self.template, expected_status='CREATE_COMPLETE') stack = self.client.stacks.get(stack_id) asg_size = self._stack_output(stack, 'asg_size') # Ensure that initial desired capacity is met self.assertEqual(3, asg_size) # send scale down signals and ensure that asg honors min_size asg = self.client.resources.get(stack_id, 'random_group') min_size = 2 for num in range(asg_size-1, 0, -1): expected_resources = num if num >= min_size else min_size self.client.resources.signal(stack_id, 'scale_down_policy') test.call_until_true(self.conf.build_timeout, self.conf.build_interval, self.check_autoscale_complete, asg.physical_resource_id, expected_resources) expected_resources = {'random_group': 'OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup', 'scale_up_policy': 'OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy', 'scale_down_policy': 'OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy'}
deleted_lines: max_size: 10 min_size: 10 value_5: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.5.value]} value_9: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.9.value]} max_size: 10 min_size: 10 value_5: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.5.random_str]} value_9: value: {get_attr: [random_group, resource.9.random_str]} self.assertEqual(10, len(all_values)) self.assertEqual(all_values[5], self._stack_output(stack, 'value_5')) self.assertEqual(all_values[9], self._stack_output(stack, 'value_9')) expected_resources = {'random_group': 'OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup'}

commit_message:
Revert "Adjust logrotate configuration to use date suffix"

Actually this is not covering all requirements described in the bug-report, such as setting dateext for logrotate.conf

This reverts commit 90419d9f8a413d19c3ceb1c1e8baebb94a92ee37.

Change-Id: Ic7a45896f0a214628d849f9a5791453e2816c9b6

commit_message:
Revert "Adjust logrotate configuration to use date suffix"

Actually this is not covering all requirements described in the bug-report, such as setting dateext for logrotate.conf

This reverts commit fdcf1dd6369aeb3937e41eb80396ac1450560392.

Change-Id: Ic65cfb5c8c517cf5d2664cad0020327c399e4251

commit_message:
Use initAction() instead initScope()

initScope() for actions is deprecated in Ocata.[1]
This patch use initAction() instead initScope().
New scope is now provided as the second argument of perform().

[1]:https://review.openstack.org/#/c/345145/

Change-Id: Ie96f24fe7a892da29e4e2d80cfb100d2f3105c49

commit_message:
Use generic keystoneauth plugin identity interfaces

This allows us to use versionless endpoints for keystone in the
configuration files and furthermore, we won't depend on a specific
keystone version, as is the case today.

Change-Id: I124c0ea2d9403d6b530b33f18896c4e7bf4eabb5
Depends-On: I35f1c9dcd20017b9c442b04c142e46cad4d15eb4

deleted_lines: return identity.V3Password( return identity.V3Token( return identity.V3Token(

commit_message:
identify independent projects properly in list-changes

We may not have a value for the release model if the file is in the
_independent directory. In that case, show that we assume that the model
is independent.

Change-Id: Ica9a72356a65c20e58b8ea24da396a6d9a84b132
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/00/404300/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: series = os.path.basename( os.path.dirname( os.path.abspath(filename) ) ) if series == '_independent': default_model = 'independent' else: default_model = 'no release model specified' print(deliverable_info.get('release-model', default_model))
deleted_lines: print(deliverable_info.get('release-model', 'no release model specified')) series = os.path.basename( os.path.dirname( os.path.abspath(filename) ) )

commit_message:
Skip further tests if SHA doesn't exist

If the SHA doesn't exist, there is no point in running extra
ancestry / branch match checks and report extra errors which
are just consequences of the blatant original error.

Change-Id: I945a8de371795ee085bb31bde7360111fc81e257
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/87/404787/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # No point in running extra checks if the SHA just # doesn't exist. continue

subject: Cleanup adding Ironic to cluster on upgrade case
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-01 11:43:02.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/upgrade/upgrade.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/3cbe7202b7ccd1fb2cd0087d4dba801784462d27', 'message': "Cleanup adding Ironic to cluster on upgrade case

Grenade is designed to upgrade services. We shouldn't add them during
upgrade. This patch removes case when we trying to add Ironic to cluster
on upgrade.

Change-Id: Id7159aac8c8a343e3d20561cedc4722d87d3e776
"}]
commit_message:
Cleanup adding Ironic to cluster on upgrade case

Grenade is designed to upgrade services. We shouldn't add them during
upgrade. This patch removes case when we trying to add Ironic to cluster
on upgrade.

Change-Id: Id7159aac8c8a343e3d20561cedc4722d87d3e776
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/90/405290/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: function is_nova_migration { # Deterine whether we're "upgrading" from another compute driver # read localrc from the end, pick only first match _ironic_old_driver=$( tac $BASE_DEVSTACK_DIR/localrc |grep -m 1 VIRT_DRIVER | awk -F '=' '{print $2}') [ "$_ironic_old_driver" != "ironic" ] } # Duplicate all required devstack setup that is needed before starting # Ironic during a sideways upgrade, where we are migrating from an # devstack environment without Ironic. function init_ironic { # We need to source credentials here but doing so in the gate will unset # HOST_IP. local tmp_host_ip=$HOST_IP source $TARGET_DEVSTACK_DIR/openrc admin admin HOST_IP=$tmp_host_ip IRONIC_BAREMETAL_BASIC_OPS="True" $TARGET_DEVSTACK_DIR/tools/install_prereqs.sh initialize_database_backends recreate_database ironic utf8 install_nova_hypervisor configure_nova_hypervisor configure_ironic_dirs create_ironic_cache_dir configure_ironic create_ironic_accounts configure_tftpd configure_iptables configure_ironic_auxiliary upload_baremetal_ironic_deploy stop_nova_compute || true start_nova_compute }# If we are sideways upgrading and migrating from a base deployed /w # VIRT_DRIVER=fake, we need to run Ironic install, config and init # code from devstac. if is_nova_migration ; then init_ironic fi

commit_message:
Kolla-Kubernetes Vagrant development environment documentation

This is very much a work in progress, but describes the basic
setup of a vagrant/ansible based development environment for
kolla kubernetes. Based on halcyon-kubernetes, it uses kubeadm
to set up a kubernetes cluster running either CentOS or Ubuntu
with helm, ceph mounting support on the hosts, and host access
to the k8s dns service.

Implements: blueprint kubeadm-quickstart

Change-Id: I472fc8f02f3d56d170d1988f611a220d9232a8ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/93/404493/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. devenvironment_quickstart: ========================================== Kolla Kubernetes Dev Environment ========================================== Install Vagrant ================ Currently a Vagrant version <1.9.0 is required. Either from https://www.vagrantup.com/ or if you are on linux with libvirt, via the following instructions: ## CentOS 7.2 :: sudo yum install -y https://releases.hashicorp.com/vagrant/1.8.1/vagrant_1.8.1_x86_64.rpm # Now lets install the deps for vagrant libvirt: sudo yum install -y libvirt \ libxslt-devel \ libxml2-devel \ libvirt-devel \ libguestfs-tools-c \ ruby-devel \ gcc \ git \ git-review \ gcc-c++ #and the libvirt plugin itself vagrant plugin install vagrant-libvirt #setup libvirt access sudo to root: cat > /etc/polkit-1/rules.d/80-libvirt-manage.rules <<EOF polkit.addRule(function(action, subject) { if (action.id == "org.libvirt.unix.manage" && subject.local && subject.active && subject.isInGroup("wheel")) { return polkit.Result.YES; } }); EOF usermod -aG libvirt <your username> # Install ansible sudo yum install -y epel-release sudo yum install -y ansible #start libvirt sudo systemctl start libvirtd sudo systemctl enable libvirtd Obtain sources for building the environment =========================== The dev environemt requires you to clone two git repo's :: git clone https://github.com/att-comdev/halcyon-vagrant-kubernetes git clone https://github.com/portdirect/halcyon-kubernetes Setup environment =========================== Then move into the ```halcyon-vagrant-kubernetes``` dir and edit the config.rb file to meet your reqirements: :: # Kubernetes Details: Instances $kube_version = "centos/7" $kube_memory = 4096 $kube_vcpus = 2 $kube_count = 4 $git_commit = "6a7308d" $subnet = "192.168.236" $public_iface = "eth1" $forwarded_ports = {} # Ansible Declarations: #$number_etcd = "kube[1:2]" #$number_master = "kube[1:2]" #$number_worker = "kube[1:3]" $kube_masters = "kube1" $kube_workers = "kube[2:4]" $kube_control = "kube1" # Virtualbox leave / Openstack change to OS default username: $ssh_user = "centos" $ssh_keypath = "~/.ssh/id_rsa" $ssh_port = 22 # Ansible Details: $ansible_limit = "all" $ansible_playbook = "../halcyon-kubernetes/kube-deploy/kube-deploy.yml" $ansible_inventory = ".vagrant/provisioners/ansible/inventory_override" # Openstack Authentication Information: $os_auth_url = "http://your.openstack.url:5000/v2.0" $os_username = "user" $os_password = "password" $os_tenant = "tenant" # Openstack Instance Information: $os_flavor = "m1.small" $os_image = "centos-7.2" $os_floatnet = "public" $os_fixednet = ['vagrant-net'] $os_keypair = "your_ssh_keypair" $os_secgroups = ["default"] # Proxy Configuration (only use if deploying behind a proxy): $proxy_enable = false $proxy_http = "http://proxy:8080" $proxy_https = "https://proxy:8080" $proxy_no = "localhost,127.0.0.1" When editing this file you can change ```$ansible_playbook``` to point to the dir containing the halcyon-kubernetes repo. You can also adjust the number of kube workers (note that the first node will only run k8s pods by default), but you will then need to adjust ```$kube_workers``` accordingly Managing and interacting with the environment =========================== Now you can run: - ```vagrant up``` to create a kube cluster, running under CentOS, with romana CNI networking, Ceph clients installed and helm - ```vagrant destroy``` to make it all go away. - ```./get-k8s-creds.sh``` to get the k8s credentials for the cluster and setup kubectl on your host to access it. If you have helm installed on your host[2], you can then run ```helm init``` on your local machine and should be able to work outside of the cluster if desired. - ```vagrant ssh kube1``` to ssh into the master node Note that it will take a few minutes for everthing to be operational, on my machine it typically takes 2-4 mins after vagrant/ansible has finished for all services to be online. This is as it takes time for the images to be pulled, and CNI networking to come up, DNS is usually the last thing to be active. You can test that everything is working by running: ``` kubectl run -i -t $(uuidgen) --image=busybox --restart=Never ``` and then once inside the container: ``` nslookup kubernetes ``` To set the cluster up for developing kolla-k8s: you will most likley want to run the following command: ``` kubectl get nodes -L kubeadm.alpha.kubernetes.io/role --no-headers | awk '$NF ~ /^<none>/ { print $1}' | while read NODE ; do kubectl label node $NODE --overwrite node-type=storage kubectl label node $NODE --overwrite openstack-control-plane=enabled done ``` This will mark all the workers as being avaible for both storage and api pods. To test that helm is working in the env you just created you can run the following to smoke test: ``` helm init --client-only helm repo update helm install stable/mysql helm ls # and to check via kubectl kubectl get all ``` The pods will not provision, in this example and be shown as pending as there is no dymanic pvc creation within the cluster *yet*.

commit_message:
update PROCESS.rst for branch automation

Now that branches can be created on demand, update the process document
to replace the manual instructions with reminders and review
instructions.

Change-Id: I1d8ef79281b937543d9dbf22bf97d7593301f0e9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/22/404922/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 4. Ensure that final releases for libraries also include the specification to create the stable/$series branch.3. Ensure the stable/$series branch is requested with each client library final release.1. Ensure all RC1 tag requests include the info to have the stable/$series branch created, too. Branches for cycle-trailing and cycle-with-intermediary projects should be created when the PTL/liaison are ready, and not necessarily for RC1 week. created, use ``make_branch.sh`` to create the stable/$series
deleted_lines: 4. Create stable/$series branches for the libraries after their final release is prepared using ``branch_from_yaml.sh``.3. Create stable/$series branches for the client libraries after their final release is prepared using ``branch_from_yaml.sh``, or all together by running ``batch-stable-branches`` to build the list of commands. For example:: $ cd ~/repos/openstack-infra/release-tools $ batch-stable-branches --releases-repo ~/repos/openstack/releases --tag type:library newton > /tmp/make_newton_lib_branches.sh $ more /tmp/make_newton_lib_branches.sh $ cd ~/repos/openstack-infra/project-config/jenkins/scripts/release-tools $ bash -x /tmp/make_newton_lib_branches.sh 2>&1 | tee -a branch.log1. Create stable/$series branches for projects after their RC1 is tagged using ``branch_from_yaml.sh``. We do not create branches for cycle-trailing projects automatically, because we anticipate more release candidates for them than for other projects. Ask the PTL/liaison when they want their branch created (from which RC). created, use ``make_stable_branch.sh`` to create the stable/$series

section of the Fuel User Guide.

commit_message:
Validate first tags are on the right branch

For the first tag in the series, we skipped the descendant
check, which means that an existing SHA from a wrong branch
would pass checks. This change adds a branch match check to
cover that specific case and emit an error.

This change removes a warning which was emitted for first
releases, so we adjust the expected warning counts for some
impacted tests.

Change-Id: I741449a11ea68caeadd5be4aef8d0130efb5f5ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/86/404786/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_branch_sha(workdir, repo, series, master, sha): "Check if the SHA is in the targeted branch." if series == master: remote_match = 'master' else: remote_match = 'remotes/origin/stable/%s' % series try: output = subprocess.check_output( ['git', 'branch', '-a', '--contains', sha], cwd=os.path.join(workdir, repo), ).strip() for branch in output.split(): if branch == remote_match: return True return False except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e: print('ERROR checking SHA on branch: %s [%s]' % (e, e.output.strip())) return False

[UG] Adds VXLAN support for OVS-DPDK

Adds VXLAN support to the Configure SR-IOV and DPDK
section of the Fuel User Guide.

Change-Id: I1ba8061ec772b23d54356e896f2a9c5534694b20

commit_message:
Add keystone VirtualHost for port 443 when USE_SSL is True

Add a VirtualHost that defines the necessary options for
enabling SSL. The existing keystone Apache configuration already
does all the location handling.

Change-Id: I836a471a7258f14f051d3dd8bdb428286b5a11aa

subject: Remove unnessary assertIsNotNone
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-01 08:59:25.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/volume/test_volumes_get.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/8a6f9c339179f6f3fe9da75ff1f7b05154315fee', 'message': "Remove unnessary assertIsNotNone

If volume['id'] is None, wait_for_volume_status will fail, so
there is no need to check whether volume['id'] is None after
wait_for_volume_status.

Besides, name_field and descrip_field are only used in one function,
so it is no need to define them in resource_setup as instance

Change-Id: I2606509b2e373c37f6bdb5c3e78d84d0131ccf0b
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unnessary assertIsNotNone

If volume['id'] is None, wait_for_volume_status will fail, so
there is no need to check whether volume['id'] is None after
wait_for_volume_status.

Besides, name_field and descrip_field are only used in one function,
so it is no need to define them in resource_setup as instance
variables.

Change-Id: I2606509b2e373c37f6bdb5c3e78d84d0131ccf0b

commit_message:
Port test_serversV21 to Python 3

* Use encodeutils from oslo.utils to convert things as needed.

* Use base64 module from oslo.serialization to encode text.

Partially-Implements: blueprint goal-python35

Change-Id: I489e3b38021c45d7070bd5fae2deec6cab577745

commit_message:
Introduce PowerVMLiveMigrateData

This change set brings the PowerVMLiveMigrateData object into nova.
This allows consumers using the external nova-powervm driver to install
that driver *only* on compute nodes.

Change-Id: I69bf778fc7aa572d97ed7cddf80eaa9a30015e01
Partially-Implements: blueprint powervm-nova-compute-driver

commit_message:
Refactor _notify_about_instance_action()

Refactoring method to include call to
compute.utils.notify_about_instance_action(). Uses helper method in
objects.fields.NotificationActions.parse_notification_action_and_phase() to
create action and phase for versioned notification call. Sending of versioned
notification method will not be called when versioned notification action and
phase are not defined in the NotificationAction and NotificationPhase enum.

Change-Id: Ie6cb71ccd138ab7b5e1f535de92f4231cdb2b59b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/90/344990/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _notify_about_instance_usage(self, context, instance, action, phase=None, network_info=None, system_metadata=None, extra_usage_info=None, fault=None): """Send legacy and versioned notifications about an instance. :param:context: security context :param:instance: a nova.objects.Instance object :param:action: the name of the action :param:phase: the phase of the action, if any :param:network_info: Networking information, if provided :param:system_metadata: system_metadata DB entries for the instance, if provided. :param:extra_usage_info: Dictionary containing extra values to add or override in the notification, if provided :param:fault: fault, if provided """ event_suffix = fields.NotificationAction.to_legacy_event_suffix( action, phase=phase) compute_utils.notify_about_instance_action( context, instance, self.host, action=action, phase=phase)
deleted_lines: def _notify_about_instance_usage(self, context, instance, event_suffix, network_info=None, system_metadata=None, extra_usage_info=None, fault=None):

commit_message:
ignore deliverable files with no releases listed

We want to allow deliverable files with project metadata but without any
releases. Update the script for detecting changes in deliverable files
to skip those files.

Change-Id: I7039b8344caaa053ae29913699fa8467283722ba
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/20/406120/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update release note for fix to required args

Help for ironic commands was changed to show any required arguments
in a different section from the optional arguments in
b0641b1d996e78d6f771e3c635d684c27988bf37.

The release note is updated to clarify that this change would
be for any command, even though only two are affected by it now.

Change-Id: I9a69b3762bf9d08985d512f7ddf806e0d0d24929
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/45/405445/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Where applicable, help for commands will output the required arguments in a separate section from the optional arguments. For example, the commands ``ironic help node-create`` and ``ironic help port-create``.
deleted_lines: Starting with this release the output of commands ``ironic help node-create`` and ``ironic help port-create`` will show which arguments are required

commit_message:
First commit of charm-manila-generic

The generic manila charm provides the generic backend NFS configuration
for the manila file service charm (charm-manila).  This is the first
commit of code, and the CI tests have been disabled to enable it to
land.  This is because of a circular dependency with the manila charm
which requires this charm to be able to configure at least one backend.

This patchset is dependent on the interface-manila-plugin interface and
an updated version of charms.openstack that provides the 'options'
member: these are declared below.

Change-Id: I052f272dcd310091d988afd7104dea68115053ac
Depends-On: Ied0ad014ab7b1d4778113b0d3f2bbae08075372e
Depends-On: If6d103b4f62c95b0fa76562a18e418e0d319e987

commit_message:
First commit of manila charm

This patchset contains the code/charm for a working manila fileshare
service. On its own, the fileshare the charm installs is not functional
as a backend is needed. The charm-manila-generic plugin charm is
provided separately to provide the generic NFS file share service.

This patchset also includes the amulet/bundle tests to test that the
charm installs the manila software and can get it running.  However, no
functional tests of the actual manila software are done.

This patchset is dependent on the interface-manila-plugin interface and
an updated version of charms.openstack that provides the 'options'
member. It also depends on a slight change to the
interface-neutron-plugin which adds a requires.py to allow it to be used
to plugin to principal charms: these are declared below.

Change-Id: Ie9bb7af1baab8b3bc20d26d907d9b51957eb326e
Depends-On: Ied0ad014ab7b1d4778113b0d3f2bbae08075372e
Depends-On: If6d103b4f62c95b0fa76562a18e418e0d319e987
Depends-On: I8760f2f9bec85ccc8b149b9560a6eed3e9ab418b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-manila refs/changes/23/397923/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Canonical Ltd # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # The manila handlers class # bare functions are provided to the reactive handlers to perform the functions # needed on the class. from __future__ import absolute_import import re import subprocess import charmhelpers.core.hookenv as hookenv import charms_openstack.charm import charms_openstack.adapters import charms_openstack.ip as os_ip # note that manila-common is pulled in via the other packages. PACKAGES = ['manila-api', 'manila-data', 'manila-scheduler', 'manila-share', 'python-pymysql', 'python-apt', # for subordinate neutron-openvswitch if needed. ] MANILA_DIR = '/etc/manila/' MANILA_CONF = MANILA_DIR + "manila.conf" MANILA_LOGGING_CONF = MANILA_DIR + "logging.conf" MANILA_API_PASTE_CONF = MANILA_DIR + "api-paste.ini" # select the default release function and ssl feature charms_openstack.charm.use_defaults('charm.default-select-release') def strip_join(s, divider=" "): """Cleanup the string passed, split on whitespace and then rejoin it cleanly :param s: A sting to cleanup, remove non alpha chars and then represent the string. :param divider: The joining string to put the bits back together again. :returns: string """ return divider.join( re.split(r'\s+', re.sub(r'([^\s\w-])+', '', (s or "")))) ### # Compute some options to help with template rendering @charms_openstack.adapters.config_property def computed_share_backends(config): """Determine the backend protocols that are provided as a string. This asks the charm class what the backend protocols are, and then provides it as a space separated list of backends. :param config: the config option on which to look up config options :returns: string """ return ' '.join(config.charm_instance.configured_backends) @charms_openstack.adapters.config_property def computed_share_protocols(config): """Return a list of protocols as a comma (no space) separated list. The default protocols are CIFS,NFS. :param config: the config option on which to look up config options :returns: string """ return strip_join(config.share_protocols, ',').upper() @charms_openstack.adapters.config_property def computed_backend_lines_manila_conf(config): """Return the list of lines from the backends that need to go into the various configuration files. This one is for manila.conf :returns list of lines: the config for the manila.conf file """ return config.charm_instance.config_lines_for(MANILA_CONF) @charms_openstack.adapters.config_property def computed_debug_level(config): """Return NONE, INFO, WARNING, DEBUG depending on the settings of options.debug and options.level :returns: string, NONE, WARNING, DEBUG """ if not config.debug: return "NONE" if config.verbose: return "DEBUG" return "WARNING" ### # Implementation of the Manila Charm classes class ManilaCharm(charms_openstack.charm.HAOpenStackCharm): """ManilaCharm provides the specialisation of the OpenStackCharm functionality to manage a manila unit. """ release = 'mitaka' name = 'manila' packages = PACKAGES api_ports = { 'manila-api': { os_ip.PUBLIC: 8786, os_ip.ADMIN: 8786, os_ip.INTERNAL: 8786, }, } service_type = 'manila' # manila needs a second service type as well - there is a custom connect # function to set both service types. service_type_v2 = 'manilav2' default_service = 'manila-api' services = ['manila-api', 'manila-scheduler', 'manila-share', 'manila-data'] # Note that the hsm interface is optional - defined in config.yaml required_relations = ['shared-db', 'amqp', 'identity-service'] restart_map = { MANILA_CONF: services, MANILA_API_PASTE_CONF: services, MANILA_LOGGING_CONF: services, } # This is the command to sync the database sync_cmd = ['sudo', 'manila-manage', 'db', 'sync'] # ha_resources = ['vips', 'haproxy'] # Custom charm configuration def install(self): """Called when the charm is being installed or upgraded. The available configuration options need to be check AFTER the charm is installed to check to see whether it is blocked or can go into service. """ super().install() # this creates the /etc/nova directory for the # neutron-openvswitch plugin if needed. subprocess.check_call(["mkdir", "-p", "/etc/nova"]) self.assess_status() def custom_assess_status_check(self): """Verify that the configuration provided is valid and thus the service is ready to go. This will return blocked if the configuraiton is not valid for the service. :returns (status: string, message: string): the status, and message if there is a problem. Or (None, None) if there are no issues. """ options = self.options # tiny optimisation for less typing. backends = options.computed_share_backends if not backends: return 'blocked', 'No share backends configured' default_share_backend = options.default_share_backend if not default_share_backend: return 'blocked', "'default-share-backend' is not set" if default_share_backend not in backends: return ('blocked', "'default-share-backend:{}' is not a configured backend" .format(default_share_backend)) return None, None def get_amqp_credentials(self): """Provide the default amqp username and vhost as a tuple. :returns (username, host): two strings to send to the amqp provider. """ return (self.options.rabbit_user, self.options.rabbit_vhost) def get_database_setup(self): """Provide the default database credentials as a list of 3-tuples returns a structure of: [ {'database': <database>, 'username': <username>, 'hostname': <hostname of this unit> 'prefix': <the optional prefix for the database>, }, ] :returns [{'database': ...}, ...]: credentials for multiple databases """ return [ dict( database=self.options.database, username=self.options.database_user, hostname=hookenv.unit_private_ip(), ) ] def register_endpoints(self, keystone): """Custom function to register the TWO keystone endpoints that this charm requires. 'charm' and 'charmv2'. :param keystone: the keystone relation on which to setup the endpoints """ # regsiter the first endpoint self._custom_register_endpoints(keystone, 'v1', self.service_type, self.region, self.public_url, self.internal_url, self.admin_url) # regsiter the second endpoint self._custom_register_endpoints(keystone, 'v2', self.service_type_v2, self.region, self.public_url_v2, self.internal_url_v2, self.admin_url_v2) @staticmethod def _custom_register_endpoints(keystone, prefix, service, region, public_url, internal_url, admin_url): """Custom function to enable registering of multiple endpoints. Keystone charm understands multiple endpoints if they are prefixed with a string_ as in 'v1_service' and 'v2_service', etc. However, the keystone interface doesn't know how to do this. Therefore, this function duplicates part of that functionality but enables the 'multiple' endpoints to be set :param keystone: the relation that is keystone. :param prefix: the prefix to prepend to '_<var>' :param service: the service to set :param region: the OS region :param public_url: the public_url :param internal_url: the internal_url :prarm admin_url: the admin url. """ relation_info = { '{}_service'.format(prefix): service, '{}_public_url'.format(prefix): public_url, '{}_internal_url'.format(prefix): internal_url, '{}_admin_url'.format(prefix): admin_url, '{}_region'.format(prefix): region, } keystone.set_local(**relation_info) keystone.set_remote(**relation_info) @property def public_url(self): return super().public_url + "/v1/%(tenant_id)s" @property def admin_url(self): return super().admin_url + "/v1/%(tenant_id)s" @property def internal_url(self): return super().internal_url + "/v1/%(tenant_id)s" @property def public_url_v2(self): return super().public_url + "/v2/%(tenant_id)s" @property def admin_url_v2(self): return super().admin_url + "/v2/%(tenant_id)s" @property def internal_url_v2(self): return super().internal_url + "/v2/%(tenant_id)s" @property def configured_backends(self): """Return a list of configured backends that come from the associated 'manila-share.available' state.. TODO: Note that the first backend that becomes 'available' will set this state. It's not clear how multiple backends will interact yet! :returns: list of strings: backend sections that are configured. """ adapter = self.get_adapter('manila-plugin.available') if adapter is None: return [] # adapter.names is a property that provides a list of backend manila # plugin names for the sections return adapter.relation.names def config_lines_for(self, config_file): """Return the list of configuration lines for `config_file` as returned by manila-plugin backend charms. TODO: Note that it is not clear how we get this from multiple plugin charms -- still to be worked out :param config_file: string, filename for configuration lines :returns: list of strings: config lines for `config_file` """ adapter = self.get_adapter('manila-plugin.available') if adapter is not None: # get the configuration data for all plugins config_data = adapter.relation.get_configuration_data() if config_file not in config_data: return [] config_lines = [] for section, lines in config_data[config_file].items(): if section == 'complete': # if the 'lines' is not truthy, then this conf isn't # complete, so just break out. if not lines: break continue config_lines.append(section) config_lines.extend(lines) config_lines.append('') return config_lines return []

commit_message:
Using assertIsNone() instead of assertEqual(None, ...)

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines[1]:
[H203] Unit test assertions tend to give better messages for more
specific assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred
over assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(None, ...)

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises

Change-Id: I14f54cbb7dce27e70fed4ef1cb85748474f54fc5

commit_message:
Add logical_operator in trigger definitions

The default value is "or" but let's make things explicit and set
logical_operator to "or" in every trigger.

Change-Id: I2e93ac927167d59da4fc0da1047cc0307185c301

commit_message:
Fix bug in cluster definitions

Fix a bug in the alarm cluster definitions where the state of the Nova
compute service was a member of the nova_control cluster instead of the
nova_compute cluster.

Change-Id: I828f9974d1ce1380994c1f38214b4536724c9280

commit_message:
Fix i18n hacking for trove/common

This is one of many commits that will be fixing i18n hacking checks
in Trove.

Translation checks include:
 * validate_log_translation: Logs require translation hints
 * no_translate_debug_logs: Don't transate debug level logs
 * check_raised_localization_exception: Translate exception message

Change-Id: I50e551164677b7df9d51ae086cbedcce0cea109f

commit_message:
Disable notifications for cinder when no consumer

Notifications for cinder is not disabled when there is no other consuming
project, it's better to disable that to reduce some pressure for the message
bus[1].

[1]:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.messaging/FAQ.html#i-don-t-need-notifications-on-the-message-bus-how-do-i-disable-them

Change-Id: I41c16b4ef6437b0104d4f37daa8b8640db7fdd50
Closes-bug: #1642440

Fix disabling of old murano services

Because of bug in fuel-yaql there is no other way as using
some hardcoded ps-similar constructions.

commit_message:
Fix neutron dependency on stable/newton branch

Currently master is used, and leads to gate check failures as we get
master neutron with newton neutron-lib, like for:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/400396/

Change-Id: Ie27f48b4c62816def8339e69bb373ea304937daf

subject: libvirt: Don't re-resize disks in finish_migration()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-17 12:21:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dbfef4e8c0ba341f8f2156f4ce8dc80dc981ecc6', 'message': "libvirt: Don't re-resize disks in finish_migration()

finish_migration is called by finish_resize() in compute manager,
which has updated the instance size and flavor before calling us. This
means that _create_image has already resized disks and (where
possible) their contained filesystems by calling cache() with the
correct size. That makes the additional resize in finish_migration a
no-op.

Additionally _create_image will have handled all ephemeral disks
correctly, which the no-op code did not.

Change-Id: I58a286ebfdbfd22c1360880dda8e7a4ec9df8625

commit_message:
libvirt: Don't re-resize disks in finish_migration()

finish_migration is called by finish_resize() in compute manager,
which has updated the instance size and flavor before calling us. This
means that _create_image has already resized disks and (where
possible) their contained filesystems by calling cache() with the
correct size. That makes the additional resize in finish_migration a
no-op.

Implements: bp/libvirt-imagebackend-refactor
Change-Id: I58a286ebfdbfd22c1360880dda8e7a4ec9df8625

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-25 01:06:20.000000000', 'files': ['elements/os-refresh-config/element-deps'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/866bf14ca20a5c72efe27952e8baa11824800466', 'message': "Don't depend on os-collect-config element

Nothing in the os-refresh-config element actually depends on the
os-collect-config element.

Also the os-collect-config element is being replaced by the
tripleo-puppet-element overcloud-agent element.

Currently the os-collect-config (or overcloud-agent) elements are
specified explicitly by image builders in the root elements list, so
removing it here has no negative effect.

Change-Id: Iaf70003fdd8d1782dbcb9e0f01e6468887c6de27
"}]
commit_message:
Don't depend on os-collect-config element

Nothing in the os-refresh-config element actually depends on the
os-collect-config element.

Also the os-collect-config element is being replaced by the
tripleo-puppet-element overcloud-agent element.

Currently the os-collect-config (or overcloud-agent) elements are
specified explicitly by image builders in the root elements list, so
removing it here has no negative effect.

Change-Id: Iaf70003fdd8d1782dbcb9e0f01e6468887c6de27

commit_message:
Use the absolute path for temp templates

If the template is not in the user's t-h-t root, we should use the
absolute path instead of the one in the template since we've already
copied these files in the temp dir.

Closes-bug: #1646404

Change-Id: I9a575575fc3c0fc78848239fc7b663ca4508fcfa

commit_message:
Relax JSON input validation

Currently the JSON form input validator only passes if the value is a
valid JSON string. This doesn't accout for cases where a paramater
doesn't need to be set. This patch relaxes the validation rule so it
also allows the value to be an empty string.

Change-Id: I4d135120ac3041b223986eef8f54c4de24f20379
Closes-Bug: #1645266
(cherry picked from commit 537618fed2c393cb1fbc0b52f40951dd66e3373c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ui refs/changes/05/405205/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /* * The field is valid if the current value is either empty * or a valid JSON string. */ Formsy.addValidationRule('isJson', (values, value, otherField) => { try { return value === '' ? true : !!JSON.parse(value); }

commit_message:
Fix runValidationMessage action

This change ensures that execution output created from the message
will include complete content of the message payload except for
the execution itself

Fixes problem of the stderr and stdout not being included and
therefore validation result not being displayed properly

Change-Id: Ia3c987de2706e62f027362fff8748c8adafe27d8

commit_message:
Get overcloud DNS host entries from HostsEntry heat output

This adds the overcloud nodes (and VIP entries) to the undercloud's
/etc/hosts , which is useful if we're using FQDNs for the overcloud
endpoints.

Change-Id: I934e581962fb854903d9f7bb8b356dac4ef6c90d

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: I9a47da537d9f1554271cb8e1e7284a98d364313c
Closes-Bug: #1628580

commit_message:
Add key_manager client and API tests to tempest plugin

This change adds a configurable key_manager service client
and an api testing module to be used in a gate test.

Change-Id: Ie9d0a0c2279568b2a0ffba7a3a8010d4edc570e9
Blueprint: image-signing-experimental-gate

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_context import context from oslo_utils import importutils from tempest.lib.common import rest_client CONF = cfg.CONF class KeyManagerClient(rest_client.RestClient): def setUp(self): super(KeyManagerClient, self).setUp() self.user_context = context.RequestContext( auth_token=self.token, user=self.user_id, tenant=self.tenant_id, user_name=self.user ) cls = importutils.import_class(CONF.key_manager.api_class) self.key_manager_api = cls(CONF) def create_key(self, algorithm, length, expiration=None, name=None): return self.key_manager_api.create_key(self.user_context, algorithm, length, expiration, name) def create_key_pair(self, algorithm, length, expiration=None, name=None): return self.key_manager_api.create_key_pair(self.user_context, algorithm, length, expiration, name) def store(self, managed_object, expiration=None): return self.key_manager_api.store(self.user_context, managed_object, expiration) def get(self, managed_object_id): return self.key_manager_api.get(self.user_context, managed_object_id) def delete(self, managed_object_id): return self.key_manager_api.delete(self.user_context, managed_object_id)

commit_message:
Add image signing scenarios to tempest plugin

This change adds a tempest scenario to the castellan
tempest plugin which tests glance and nova's image signing
functionality.

Change-Id: I2784eac6cd85c09c60bd79c65761c044bfbdf052
Depends-On: Ie9d0a0c2279568b2a0ffba7a3a8010d4edc570e9
Blueprint: image-signing-experimental-gate
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/00/405000/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import base64 import datetime from castellan.common.objects import x_509 from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import padding from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import rsa from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import serialization from cryptography import x509 from cryptography.x509.oid import NameOID from tempest import config from tempest import test from tempest_plugin import clients from tempest_plugin.tests.scenario import manager CONF = config.CONF class ImageSigningScenario(manager.KeyManagerScenarioTest): @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(manager.KeyManagerScenarioTest, cls).setup_clients() cls.key_manager_client = clients.Manager().key_manager_client def create_self_signed_certificate(cls, private_key): issuer = x509.Name([ x509.NameAttribute(NameOID.COUNTRY_NAME, 'US'), x509.NameAttribute(NameOID.STATE_OR_PROVINCE_NAME, 'CA'), x509.NameAttribute(NameOID.LOCALITY_NAME, 'San Francisco'), x509.NameAttribute(NameOID.ORGANIZATION_NAME, 'My Company'), x509.NameAttribute(NameOID.COMMON_NAME, 'Test Certificate'), ]) subject = issuer cert = x509.CertificateBuilder() cert.subject_name(subject) cert.issuer_name(issuer) cert.public_key(private_key.public_key()) cert.serial_number(x509.random_serial_number()) cert.not_valid_before(datetime.datetime.utcnow()) cert.not_valid_after( datetime.datetime.utcnow() + datetime.timedelta(days=10) ) cert.sign(private_key, hashes.SHA256(), default_backend()) return cert def sign_image(cls, image_file, private_key): signer = private_key.signer( padding.PSS( mgf=padding.MGF1(hashes.SHA256()), salt_length=padding.PSS_MAX_LENGTH ), hashes.SHA256() ) chunk_bytes = 8192 with open(image_file, 'rb') as f: chunk = f.read(chunk_bytes) while len(chunk) > 0: signer.update(chunk) signature = signer.finalize() signature_b64 = base64.b64encode(signature) return signature_b64 def store_cert(self, cert): der_encoding = cert.public_bytes(encoding=serialization.Encoding.DER) castellan_cert = x_509.x509(der_encoding) return self.key_manager_client.store(castellan_cert, None) @test.idempotent_id('549173a5-38ec-42bb-b0e2-c8b9f4a08944') @test.services('compute', 'image') def test_signed_image_upload_and_boot(self): """This test case attempts to produce the following steps: * Sign an image and upload it to Glance with signature metadata * Boot an instance from the signed image * Check the status of the instance """ private_key = rsa.generate_private_key(public_exponent=3, key_size=1024, backend=default_backend()) certificate = self.create_self_signed_certificate(private_key) cert_uuid = self.store_cert(certificate) img_signature = self.sign_image(self.img_file) img_properties = { 'img_signature': img_signature, 'img_signature_certificate_uuid': cert_uuid, 'img_signature_key_type': 'RSA-PSS', 'img_signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', } img_uuid = self._image_create( 'signed_img', CONF.scenario.img_container_format, self.img_file, disk_format=CONF.scenario.img_disk_format, properties=img_properties ) keypair = self.create_keypair() self.security_group = self._create_security_group() security_groups = [{'name': self.security_group['name']}] self.instance = self.create_server(name='signed_img_server', image_id=img_uuid, flavor=self.flavor_ref, key_name=keypair['name'], security_groups=security_groups, wait_until='ACTIVE') self.verify_ssh(keypair) self.servers_client.delete_server(self.instance['id']) @test.idempotent_id('7fff3fb3-91d9-4fd0-bc7c-0204f1f180bc') @test.services('image') def test_signed_image_upload_glance_fail(self): """This test case attempts to produce the following steps: * Upload an image to Glance with invalid signature metadata * Check that the image upload fails """ private_key = rsa.generate_private_key(public_exponent=3, key_size=1024, backend=default_backend()) certificate = self.create_self_signed_certificate(private_key) cert_uuid = self.store_cert(certificate) img_properties = { 'img_signature': 'not-a-valid-signature', 'img_signature_certificate_uuid': cert_uuid, 'img_signature_key_type': 'RSA-PSS', 'img_signature_hash_method': 'SHA-256', } img_uuid = self._image_create( 'bad_signed_img', CONF.scenario.img_container_format, self.img_file, disk_format=CONF.scenario.img_disk_format, properties=img_properties ) resp_body = self.image_client.show_image(img_uuid) self.AssertEqual('killed', resp_body['status'])

commit_message:
Feature classification

This spec extends the "feature support matrix" documentation effort
started in Nova to apply to other relevant projects.

Change-Id: I59e16e6f19590959ed85cdd98205c9dc06fc3e8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs refs/changes/47/322347/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================== Feature classification ====================== Nova recently introduced a particularly useful page in their documentation entitled `Feature Support Matrix <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/support-matrix.html>`_, which essentially communicates which features of Nova can be expected to be reliable, and expected to work in combination with which compute drivers. This provides value to both operators, who need to make intelligent decisions about driver selections, and developers, who need to manage support and maintenance expectations. Many other projects in OpenStack present similarly complex arrangements of feature availability versus driver selections, making this documentation pattern more generally useful across OpenStack beyond Nova's use case for compute drivers. Problem description =================== To quote the `user story <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-user-stories/user-stories/proposed/feature-classification.html>`_: Operators and Users lack centralized visibility into the status of the completeness, stability and documentation of features. They also lack knowledge of the effects of configuration decisions on these features and their classification. This prevents Operators from making optimal decisions when configuring their clouds and leaves their users unsure of the maturity and stability of features they might choose to use in their applications and workloads. Proposed change =============== http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/feature_classification.html Each OpenStack project should utilize the following guidelines to produce a cohesive set of feature classification matrices across OpenStack. Feature groups -------------- Feature groups are related sets of API features that are intended to be implemented by two or more drivers, giving operators a choice about which driver to deploy. Feature maturity ---------------- The feature maturity rating describes the overall state of implementation of a particular API feature or behavior, rather than that of a specific driver or deployment. - **Incomplete** features don't have enough functionality to satisfy real world use cases. - **Experimental** features should be used with extreme caution. They are likely to have little or no upstream testing. With little testing there are likely to be many unknown bugs. - **Complete** features must have: 1. **Complete API documentation**, including a conceptual overview and detailed REST call definitions. 2. **Complete administrator documentation**, including a conceptual overview, configuration, usage, operations, and troubleshooting. 3. **Tempest tests** that illustrate the feature working correctly. 4. **Sufficient functionality and reliability** for real world use cases. For example, a driver should represent a trustworthy solution to a common problem for a broad spectrum of end users. 5. **No foreseeable reasons for deprecation** in the future. For example, a feature should not be considered complete when it's only being implemented as a stop-gap measure until a longer term solution is implemented. - **Required** features are those that any new technology must support before being allowed into tree. - **Deprecated** features are those that are scheduled to be removed in a future major release of Nova. If a feature is marked as complete, it should never be deprecated. If a feature is incomplete or experimental for several releases, it runs the risk of being deprecated, and later removed from the code base. Deployment rating ----------------- The deployment rating describes the state of automated functional testing for a specific feature or behavior of a given deployment. - `unknown` implementations are not known to have relevant test coverage provided via tempest. - `not implemented` implementations do not have relevant test coverage provided via tempest. - `implemented` implementations are self-declared to be passing relevant tempest tests. - `regularly tested` (*) implementations are tested at least periodically (for example, nightly) by third party CI. - `checked` implementations are tested by required parts of a voting gate job. Alternatives ------------ Not applicable. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - Nova: John Garbutt - Neutron: Ankur Gupta - Keystone: Dolph Mathews Work Items ---------- 1. Port Nova's support_matrix extension for sphinx to a common, shared codebase where it can be centrally maintained and consumed by other projects. 2. Each project should introduce their own feature classification matrix. Dependencies ============ The following items are related: - `Feature classification blueprint <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/feature-classification>`_ in nova. - `OpenStack user story <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-user-stories/user-stories/proposed/feature-classification.html>`_. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Newton - Introduced .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
HyperVClusterDriver: ignores non-nova instances

If a failover occurs for a non-nova instance, the
HyperVClusterDriver will now ignore that instance.

Closes-Bug: #1646804

commit_message:
Retry port create to deal with race condition.

Retry to deal with a race condition between multiple neutron servers.
It's possible to have a network created on one controller and then a
port created on a different controller quickly enough that the second
controller does not yet see that network in its local cache of the
OVN northbound database.  A simple retry gives this controller an
opportunity to catch up.

Change-Id: Icbf41d7336663d05499c70b76e4cc8a88d4d9081
Closes-bug: #1646111
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>

A simple retry gives this controller an # opportunity to catch up. @tenacity.retry(retry=tenacity.retry_if_exception_type(RuntimeError), wait=tenacity.wait_exponential(), stop=tenacity.stop_after_delay(10), reraise=True)

commit_message:
Skip docstring checks (H4xx) if using pep257

If flake8_docstrings is available, than the normal flake8 run will
include corresponding pep257 checks for each of the current checks in
hacking.checks.docstrings. In that case, we can make them no-ops to
avoid raising two different error codes for a single violation.

Change-Id: I24353210c4985b9cfb7e631ff5c9d55c8c5c08a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/94/239094/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functoolsdef skip_if_flake8_docstrings_is_available(f): """Skip the decorated check if flake8-docstrings is available. flake8-docstrings provides pep257 as a plugin to flake8. If it's available, the checks provided by pep257 are a superset of the ones found here, so these checks can be skipped. See pep257's `full list of error codes <http://pep257.readthedocs.org/en/latest/error_codes.html>`_ for more reference. """ @functools.wraps(f) def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): try: import flake8_docstrings except ImportError: # Only call the wrapped function if flake8_docstrings is not # available. return f(*args, **kwargs) else: # If flake8_docstrings is not available, return what flake8 expects # to see when checks pass. return None return wrapper @skip_if_flake8_docstrings_is_available # Redundant with pep257's D210.@skip_if_flake8_docstrings_is_available # Redundant with pep257's D209.@skip_if_flake8_docstrings_is_available # Redundant with pep257's D210.@skip_if_flake8_docstrings_is_available # Redundant with pep257's D205.

subject: Validate the value of remove_in
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-03 21:06:24.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_log/versionutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log/commit/b50f92bf24ad6f41ac64825136bcd48d55496ba3', 'message': 'Validate the value of remove_in

A recent code review [1] spawned a discussion about the utility of
non-positive values of remove_in, including zero. These are not intended
or supported use cases for the deprecated() decorator, as the resulting
deprecation messages ("this feature was deprecated in the A release
cycle to be removed in the A release cycle" or "this feature was
deprecated in the B release cycle to be removed in the A release cycle",
ultimately do not make sense and defeat the purpose of a deprecation
cycle.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/287413/1/keystone/revoke/core.py

Change-Id: I01bca69db82f2f673afcfad7e17bce00959e6039
'}]
commit_message:
Validate the value of remove_in

A recent code review [1] spawned a discussion about the utility of
non-positive values of remove_in, including zero. These are not intended
or supported use cases for the deprecated() decorator, as the resulting
deprecation messages ("this feature was deprecated in the A release
cycle to be removed in the A release cycle" or "this feature was
deprecated in the B release cycle to be removed in the A release cycle",
ultimately do not make sense and defeat the purpose of a deprecation
cycle.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/287413/1/keystone/revoke/core.py

Change-Id: I01bca69db82f2f673afcfad7e17bce00959e6039
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/27/288127/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: deprecated, the release where it may be considered for removal and possibly an optional replacement. It also logs a message when a deprecated exception is being caught in a try-except block, but not when subclasses of that exception are being caught. _remove_in_validation_msg = _( 'remove_in must be a positive integer (indicating when a feature ' 'may be removed), or null (indicating that a ' 'feature will never ' 'be removed).') :param remove_in: a positive integer specifying how many releases to wait before removing (default: 2) if remove_in is not None and not isinstance(remove_in, int): raise TypeError(self._remove_in_validation_msg) elif isinstance(remove_in, int) and remove_in <= 0: raise ValueError(self._remove_in_validation_msg)
deleted_lines: deprecated, the release where it may be removed and possibly an optional replacement. It also logs a message when a deprecated exception is being caught in a try-except block, but not when subclasses of that exception are being caught. :param remove_in: an integer specifying how many releases to wait before removing (default: 2)

commit_message:
Always use memcached

Keystone should always use memcached, especially with Fernet. Without
caching, Fernet token validation performance suffers dramatically.

Granted, memcached is also strictly required if you set your token
backend to 'memcache', but that's a different and confusing topic.

Change-Id: Idd668ddbcb68e6a6e2d88521753339ec00368f82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone refs/changes/48/326748/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: when: - "'memcache' in keystone_token_driver" - "'fernet' not in keystone_token_provider"

subject: Test revocation race conditions

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-25 18:46:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/30553965995e58aea6ecd5de51fab5a24e86d9d2', 'message': 'Test revocation race conditions

This tests a matrix of all possible race conditions that can occur
between creating tokens, revoking tokens, and validating tokens.

The goal is to err on the side of security regardless of the precision

commit_message:
Test revocation race conditions

This tests a matrix of all possible race conditions that can occur
between creating tokens, revoking tokens, and validating tokens.

The goal is to err on the side of security regardless of the precision
of timestamps used by revocation events, token formats, etc.

Change-Id: Iabe5f967a5953cbdaf57ca72ed2291ab71f73235
Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>
Related-Bug: 1473567

added_lines: class RaceConditions(test_v3.RestfulTestCase): def create_token(self): r = self.v3_authenticate_token( self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.user['id'], password=self.user['password'])) return r.headers.get('X-Subject-Token') def revocation_event(self, token=None): token = token or self.create_token() new_password = uuid.uuid4().hex self.post( '/users/%s/password' % self.user['id'], body={'user': { 'password': new_password, 'original_password': self.user['password']}}, token=token, expected_status=http_client.NO_CONTENT) self.user['password'] = new_password def validate_token(self, token, expected_status=http_client.OK): self.head( '/auth/tokens', headers={'X-Subject-Token': token}, expected_status=expected_status) def test_create_eq_revoke_eq_validate(self): token = self.create_token() self.revocation_event(token) self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.NOT_FOUND) def test_create_lt_revoke_eq_validate(self): token = self.create_token() self.revocation_event(token) self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.NOT_FOUND) def test_create_eq_revoke_lt_validate(self): token = self.create_token() self.revocation_event(token) self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.NOT_FOUND) def test_create_lt_revoke_lt_validate(self): token = self.create_token() self.revocation_event(token) self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.NOT_FOUND) def test_revoke_eq_create_eq_validate(self): # NOTE(dolph): This is the same test case as # test_create_eq_revoke_eq_validate(). pass def test_revoke_lt_create_eq_validate(self): self.revocation_event() token = self.create_token() self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.OK) def test_revoke_eq_create_lt_validate(self): # NOTE(dolph): This is the same test case as # test_create_eq_revoke_lt_validate(). pass def test_revoke_lt_create_lt_validate(self): self.revocation_event() token = self.create_token() self.validate_token(token, expected_status=http_client.OK)

commit_message:
Do not count events for every event created

We were a bit overzealous in our enforcement of
max_events_per_stack. Rather than count the number of events within a
stack every time an event is created, only do the count a small
percentage of the time (dependent on the inverse of
event_purge_batch_size). This also means that max_events_per_stack is
no longer a strict limit but a loose one.

Change-Id: I63b42a50cfc3ffa6b54413900b5e0a6c5c40943c

commit_message:
[user guide] Legacy neutron command change

Updating neutron commands to openstack commands
for the legacy to openstack conversion.

Change-Id: I3b7885ca8cf00fd65db9cbca148a106f86e3580f
Implements-blueprint: use-openstack-command

commit_message:
Remove 'super' call in obj_make_compatible

This resulted in the following error message when the function was
called, and doesn't appear to be called for non-persistent objects:

  oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError: Object action
    obj_make_compatible failed because: No rule for cpu_topology

Change-Id: Ifc49331b3692453435c6232f3463c33e2a10a87c

commit_message:
conf: Deprecate 'torrent_' options

These are not tested and the feature either needs test coverage or
should be deprecated. Take the latter option, deprecating the feature
for a cycle to see if anyone actually cares about the feature.

Change-Id: I90206e6554bcbf5cd9105aa975c447c69640c923
Implements: bp centralize-config-options-ocata

commit_message:
Move all extensions from contrib dir

All extensions from novaclient.v2.contrib should be not be extensions in
case of api version >=2.0;<=3.0 (historically, they are turned on by default
for cli layer), so let's move it from contrib dir and turn on by default.

Change-Id: I4ef4e44cf970947dad33110ce658a133e4f2893e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/26/280726/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(andreykurilin): v2.1 include all extensions from contrib dir if not extensions and self.api_version.ver_minor != 0: from novaclient import client extensions = client.discover_extensions(self.api_version)

subject: enforcement logic refactored
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-11 20:55:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/76c799169ff7f6d67b7eb643516fa49248943b8d', 'message': "Extract enforcement logic to its own method

In keystone/common/controller.py, the enforcement logic is inside the
'protected' wrapper, which is used to annotate controller methods.

This change extracts the enforcement logic to its own method, making
it possible to be called without having the 'protected' annotation.

This is specially useful when a single method needs to apply
enforcement depending on the parameters. Take change [1] as example,
which needed to write [create|get|list|update|delete]_domain_role
methods only to match the current standard using that annotation.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262078

Change-Id: I03d7c997441941761a879a7541e5273e0d7e300d
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-05 04:09:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/5597e6bd403b3de418a528870535651bb7c8d31b', 'message': "Extract enforcement logic to its own method

it possible to be called without having the 'protected' annotation.

This is specially useful when a single method needs to apply
enforcement depending on the parameters. Take change [1] as example,
which needed to write [create|get|list|update|delete]_domain_role
methods only to match the current standard using that annotation.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262078
